title: Question 81

children: A 25-year-old man is evaluated for a slightly pruritic rash that began as a single oval patch on his back.
Representative lesions on his lateral thigh are
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Pityriasis rosea classically begins with a single, pink, 2- to 4-cm, thin, oval-shaped plaque with a thin collarette of scale at the periphery (known as the herald patch), as

on a different patient. Similar but smaller plaques subsequently erupt within days to weeks, usually on the torso along skin cleavage lines in a “fir tree” distribution. Lesions may be asymptomatic or mildly itchy. Pityriasis rosea most commonly occurs during the spring or fall.
